Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: BP: CS Unplugged: Encourage Computing without Computers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Colorado School of Mines, in collaboration with the National Center for Women & Information Technology at the University of Colorado, will implement and evaluate Computer Science (CS) Unplugged activities at five middle schools in the Jefferson County Public Schools district. CS Unplugged activities are designed to engage students in computational thinking activities without using computers. Many in the CS community hypothesize that the absence of a computer and the social of the Unplugged activities make CS Unplugged especially engaging for female and under-represented minority students who tend to have less experience and confidence with computing concepts. But what is the impact of Unplugged on students? Using pre- and post-surveys and learning assessments the project team will explore a number of questions to assess the impact of Unplugged activities on students. For example, does participation in CS Unplugged activities actually have a positive impact on students' interest (especially women and underrepresented minorities) in pursuing computing as a major or career? Can exposure to CS concepts in a more accessible format (i.e., with no computers) increase students' confidence that they are able to learn the fundamentals required to continue in the field? In addition to evaluating the impact on students, the project team will explore how to effectively incorporate CS Unplugged activities in a middle-school classroom, and how to encourage middle school teachers to include CS Unplugged activities and CS concepts in their classroom instruction.

Many K-12 school students have had limited exposure to computing concepts, and therefore, have a very poor understanding of what computing education and careers involve. To address this lack of knowledge, an international community of CS Unplugged contributors has developed activities to illustrate the kind of thinking that is expected of a computer scientist. CS Unplugged activities involve problem solving to achieve a goal, and engage students via kinesthetic activities, games, magic tricks, and competitions. Studies have shown that middle school is where students' interest in computing deteriorates; thus, this project will extend CS Unplugged activities with career information and then assess the impact of the Unplugged activities in the largest school district in Colorado with significant student diversity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
There is a nationwide shortage of K-12 teachers prepared to teach STEM classes. At the same time, jobs related to Computer Science are predicted to grow by more than 20%. Furthermore, 21st century skills for all students include digital literacy, critical thinking, and problem solving.   

A set of fun, kinesthetic activities called CS Unplugged were developed by Tim Bell at the University of Canterbury to expose students to important computing concepts (e.g., binary numbers, representation of data and images, and artificial intelligence) and problem-solving approaches (e.g., binary search, minimal spanning trees, and combinatorics).   These activities have been used effectively within various informal settings, such as after-school programs and summer camps. Using the activities in the classroom presents new challenges, however, because teachers must be comfortable with lessons that minimize the role of lecture, emphasizing instead active participation by teams of students. Furthermore, to justify classroom time, teachers must be assured that students are learning fundamental computing concepts and not just having fun. 

This project addressed these challenges by creating detailed CS Unplugged lesson plans (which were piloted and then improved), hosting professional development workshops for teachers, and developing content assessments to measure student learning.

We assessed learning outcomes using two assessment measures: worksheets completed by students as part of the activities and a comprehensive project that combines knowledge from multiple activities. All assessments were scored by researchers as “proficient”, “partially proficient” or “unsatisfactory.” The percentage of students achieving a “proficient” rating was above 50% for all six assessed activities. For the three most successful activities (binary numbers, cryptography, parity and error detection), more than 85% of the students were ranked as “proficient” overall, with scores on some questions as high as 98%. 

The worksheets showed that students generally understood and were able to demonstrate the desired skills when participating in the activities,. After students had participated in all six activities, they completed a comprehensive project to determine whether they would remember and be able to apply what they had learned. As expected, scores on the comprehensive project questions were somewhat lower than on the worksheets, since students had only been exposed to each concept during one 50-minute class. Despite the limited exposure, the comprehensive results were quite encouraging, with percentage of “proficient” scores ranging from 49% to 83%. 

The target population for this project is middle school students in grades 6 through 8. Since most middle school teachers have little or no prior computing experience, we expanded the existing CS Unplugged activities with step-by-step lecture notes that teachers could follow to first learn the material themselves and then share the knowledge with their students. The lesson plans were developed and pilot tested by Computer Science students at Colorado School of Mines, then critiqued by collaborating middle school teachers. During summer 2016 we held a 2-day workshop in which 13 teachers from local school districts learned 10 different CS Unplugged activities.  As part of the workshop, we assessed teachers’ comfort level and knowledge of the material, and determined that teachers had the necessary understanding and level of desire to use the activities in their classrooms. 

Following this 2016 workshop, 14 teachers (12 who attended the workshop and 2 who just followed our online materials) deployed 61 different activities. Via follow-up surveys, teachers indicated that they were very comfortable with the lesson plans, had a “strong” or “extremely” strong knowledge, and were likely to deploy most of the activities again. 

All lesson plans are available via the project website (http://csunplugged.mines.edu) and the NCWIT CS Unplugged-in-a-box (http://www.ncwit.org/csunplugged). The activities were also promoted at the Computer Science Teachers Association (CSTA) conference and during CSPdWeek, both in July 2017. Lastly, we hosted a 2nd workshop in the summer of 2017 to expand our reach.
